articles.headline: U.S. Agency Sets Fines for Maker of Airbags
articles.snippet: The safety agency said the Japanese manufacturer had failed to respond “fully or truthfully” to demands for documents related to the defect.
articles.abstract: The safety agency said the Japanese manufacturer had failed to respond “fully or truthfully” to demands for documents related to the defect.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an escalating standoff with Takata, federal regulators said on Friday that they would begin to fine the Japanese auto supplier $14,000 a day, saying it had not fully cooperated in an investigation into defective airbags.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Currency’s Weakness Troubles China’s Policy Makers
articles.snippet: The renminbi’s value reflects money flowing out of the country, as wealthy Chinese move large sums overseas and foreign investors grow skeptical over the economy.
articles.abstract: The renminbi’s value reflects money flowing out of the country, as wealthy Chinese move large sums overseas and foreign investors grow skeptical over the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Every weekday morning this year, China’s currency has followed the same ominous path.

articles.headline: Luxury Cars Imprint Their Brands on Goods From Cologne to Clothing
articles.snippet: Upscale automakers have been affixing their aspirational logos to non-automotive products as a way of protecting brands and cultivating loyalty.
articles.abstract: Upscale automakers have been affixing their aspirational logos to non-automotive products as a way of protecting brands and cultivating loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since he was a child, Rodney Foster has coveted all things Bentley.

articles.headline: Financial Advice by the Demographics
articles.snippet: Fidelity and other retirement plan providers have begun rewriting the script when it comes to advising specific employees, including women, Hispanics and members of specific generations or income groups.
articles.abstract: Fidelity and other retirement plan providers have begun rewriting the script when it comes to advising specific employees, including women, Hispanics and members of specific generations or income groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a woman calls Fidelity about her investments there, her questions are likely to be handled a bit differently from those asked by a man.

articles.headline: In China’s Modern Economy, a Retro Push Against Women
articles.snippet: An economic boom that has created opportunities for women has also fostered a resurgence of traditional values, the idea that a woman’s place is in the home.
articles.abstract: An economic boom that has created opportunities for women has also fostered a resurgence of traditional values, the idea that a woman’s place is in the home.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Fresh out of college, Angela Li was proud of her job as a teller at the state-owned China Everbright Bank — maybe it wasn’t exciting, but it had prospects. After a year and a half she applied for a promotion, along with a male colleague who had joined with her.
articles.byline: By Didi Kirsten Tatlow and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Greek Debt Vastly Overstated, Investor Tells the World
articles.snippet: Paul Kazarian, a large investor in Greek bonds, is trying to convince others that the country’s debt is not as burdensome as it might appear.
articles.abstract: Paul Kazarian, a large investor in Greek bonds, is trying to convince others that the country’s debt is not as burdensome as it might appear.
articles.lead_paragraph: High in a Morgan Stanley office tower, Paul B. Kazarian, one of the largest holders of Greek government bonds, was recently trying to persuade a room full of investors that Greece’s debt load of 318 billion euros was actually a tenth that size.

articles.headline: In Remarks on Obama, Rudy Giuliani to the Core
articles.snippet: Mr. Giuliani, long prone to flamboyant confrontation and rhetorical excess, is less inclined toward self-restraint than ever.
articles.abstract: Mr. Giuliani, long prone to flamboyant confrontation and rhetorical excess, is less inclined toward self-restraint than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: He showed up unannounced and was initially not even invited, but he was prepared all the same.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: For Immigrants, Fear Returns After a Federal Judge’s Ruling
articles.snippet: Many are anxious now that officials indefinitely postponed an expanded immigration program offering greater protection for young unauthorized immigrants.
articles.abstract: Many are anxious now that officials indefinitely postponed an expanded immigration program offering greater protection for young unauthorized immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — For Tomás Péndola, an immigrant from Argentina, it was a normal week teaching chemistry in a public high school here, filling a whiteboard with dense equations and coaxing his students to decipher them.

articles.headline: In Service Sector, No Rest for the Working
articles.snippet: As restaurants, retailers and other businesses shrink the intervals between shifts and rely on smaller staffs to shave costs, employees are losing sleep.
articles.abstract: As restaurants, retailers and other businesses shrink the intervals between shifts and rely on smaller staffs to shave costs, employees are losing sleep.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the nights when she has just seven hours between shifts at a Taco Bell in Tampa, Fla., Shetara Brown drops off her three young children with her mother. After work, she catches a bus to her apartment, takes a shower to wash off the grease and sleeps three and a half hours before getting back on the bus to return to her job.

articles.headline: In Whole Foods Backlash, a Chance to Air Out Stagnant Boardrooms
articles.snippet: The grocery chain was ham-handed in its efforts to keep shareholders from voting on a perfectly reasonable proposal at its annual meeting this year.
articles.abstract: The grocery chain was ham-handed in its efforts to keep shareholders from voting on a perfectly reasonable proposal at its annual meeting this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Large, institutional investors in the United States are generally a passive lot. In board elections and other corporate governance matters, they’re hesitant to speak up. All too often they vote their shares in lock step with management.

articles.headline: Battle to Retake Iraqi City Looms as Test of Obama’s ISIS Strategy
articles.snippet: American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle there.
articles.abstract: American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle that is becoming a major test of the Obama administration’s strategy to stop the spread of the terrorist group in the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Bush Spouse Backs Jeb, but Is Wary of Family Business
articles.snippet: As Columba Bush wrestled with whether to support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president, her sense of duty was mixed with dread.
articles.abstract: As Columba Bush wrestled with whether to support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president, her sense of duty was mixed with dread.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — For 20 years, Columba Bush anticipated the day she would have to answer one big question: Would she support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president?
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Peter Lik’s Recipe for Success: Sell Prints. Print Money.
articles.snippet: Mr. Lik, an Australian photographer, has what many artists crave: buyers willing to spend big. But in the art world, price does not always equal value.
articles.abstract: Mr. Lik, an Australian photographer, has what many artists crave: buyers willing to spend big. But in the art world, price does not always equal value.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter Lik is in awe of himself. When he describes his career as a fine-art photographer, he speaks with the satisfaction of a guy who has performed miracles, at the pace of a bystander who just caught a glimpse of Superman. The words tumble forth in self-exalting, run-on sentences, most of them laced with profanity, all of them in the sunny, chummy accent of his native Australia.

articles.headline: Old India’s Village of Warriors Becomes Birthplace of Bouncers
articles.snippet: There are few places where historical periods slam into each other quite so forcefully as they do outside New Delhi, where musclemen whose ancestors fought invaders now defend bar patrons.
articles.abstract: There are few places where historical periods slam into each other quite so forcefully as they do outside New Delhi, where musclemen whose ancestors fought invaders now defend bar patrons.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — In a smoky nightclub on the third floor of the Sahara Mall, blowing off steam to the thudding bass line of a Bollywood dance mix, are the inhabitants of the new India — the sales representatives and software developers and call-center cubicle dwellers, all of them dancing giddily, hands flung in the air.

articles.headline: Health Care Opens Stable Career Path, Taken Mainly by Women
articles.snippet: Where industrial jobs have grown scarce, nurses and other health care professionals are increasingly leading the way to middle-income lifestyles.
articles.abstract: Where industrial jobs have grown scarce, nurses and other health care professionals are increasingly leading the way to middle-income lifestyles.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, W.Va. — For Tabitha Waugh, it was another typical day of chaos on the sixth-floor cancer ward.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Eduardo Porter and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: In Pre-Primary Pivot to Right, Walker Shifts Tone on Abortion
articles.snippet: Wisconsin’s governor, a Republican, has made shifts in how he talks about abortion and same-sex marriage since his re-election victory over a well-funded Democrat.
articles.abstract: Wisconsin’s governor, a Republican, has made shifts in how he talks about abortion and same-sex marriage since his re-election victory over a well-funded Democrat.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — It was a memorable political ad: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spoke directly into the camera in a 30-second spot last fall and called abortion an “agonizing” decision. He described himself as pro-life but, borrowing the language of the abortion rights movement, pointed to legislation he signed that leaves “the final decision to a woman and her doctor.”

articles.headline: Obama’s Expected Keystone Pipeline Veto Is Likely to Be the First in a Wave
articles.snippet: President Obama’s veto of the pipeline bill this week, the third and most significant one of his six years in office, would most likely be followed by others.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s veto of the pipeline bill this week, the third and most significant one of his six years in office, would most likely be followed by others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wielding the weapon of his pen, President Obama this week is expected to formally reject a Republican attempt to force construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline. But in stopping the transit of petroleum from the forests of Alberta to the Gulf Coast, Mr. Obama will be opening the veto era of his presidency.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Ellen Pao Suit Against Kleiner Perkins Heads to Trial, With Big Potential Implications
articles.snippet: A high-profile harassment lawsuit brought against the prominent venture capital firm comes as attention mounts on gender issues in Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: A high-profile harassment lawsuit brought against the prominent venture capital firm comes as attention mounts on gender issues in Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Many women in technology believe Silicon Valley is stuck in the past. They say they are rarely hired, promoted or taken seriously, and are confronted on a daily basis by sexism and harassment. They feel demeaned and discouraged.

articles.headline: Amid a Slump, a Crackdown for Venezuela
articles.snippet: Faced with tumbling approval ratings as Venezuelans reel from a steep currency devaluation and a crumbling economy, President Nicolás Maduro is intensifying his attacks against opponents.
articles.abstract: Faced with tumbling approval ratings as Venezuelans reel from a steep currency devaluation and a crumbling economy, President Nicolás Maduro is intensifying his attacks against opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — For a glimpse into Venezuela’s economic disarray, slip into a travel agency here and book a round-trip flight to Maracaibo, on the other side of the country, for just $16. Need a book to read on the plane? For those with hard currency, a new copy of “50 Shades of Grey” goes for $2.50. Forget your toothpaste? A tube of Colgate costs 7 cents.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Girish Gupta

articles.headline: Google and Apple Fight for the Car Dashboard
articles.snippet: In the coming months, dealerships around the country will begin selling vehicles capable of running Android- and Apple-compatible dashboard systems.
articles.abstract: In the coming months, dealerships around the country will begin selling vehicles capable of running Android- and Apple-compatible dashboard systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — When Google hosted a boot camp here this month for its Android operating system, there were some new faces in the room: auto manufacturers.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: SodaStream Hits Reset as Its Sales and Profit Fall
articles.snippet: Faced with slumping sales despite a thriving United States market for water products, the home-carbonation company is rethinking its product line.
articles.abstract: Faced with slumping sales despite a thriving United States market for water products, the home-carbonation company is rethinking its product line.
articles.lead_paragraph: SodaStream, the once-hot device for do-it-yourself sodas, is betting on the growing thirst for bubbly water to bring some sparkle back to its business.

articles.headline: World Surf League Takes Web-First Approach to Drawing Viewers
articles.snippet: As more viewers move online and audiences become more global, professional sports leagues have all adopted streaming as an important way to attract younger fans around the world, and surfing leads the way.
articles.abstract: As more viewers move online and audiences become more global, professional sports leagues have all adopted streaming as an important way to attract younger fans around the world, and surfing leads the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last December, as 21-year-old Gabriel Medina battled to be crowned surfing’s newest champion on the North Shore of Oahu, millions in his native Brazil stayed glued not to their TVs, but to their tablets, laptops and mobile phones.
articles.byline: By Talya Minsberg and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Pandora Making Bid to Unruffle Music World
articles.snippet: Pandora has created a division to work with labels and artist managers, opened its vast databanks, and begun experimenting with artist promotions.
articles.abstract: Pandora has created a division to work with labels and artist managers, opened its vast databanks, and begun experimenting with artist promotions.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Brian P. McAndrews took over as chief executive of Pandora Media in September 2013, one of his first tasks was to clear his calendar for the employee holiday party. Expecting a date in December, he was told that by Pandora tradition, the event would not be held until January or February.

articles.headline: Lawsuits’ Lurid Details Draw an Online Crowd
articles.snippet: Legal documents filed electronically, and viewed by mass audiences, are changing the narrative and the nature of cases.
articles.abstract: Legal documents filed electronically, and viewed by mass audiences, are changing the narrative and the nature of cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intimate, often painful allegations in lawsuits — intended for the scrutiny of judges and juries — are increasingly drawing in mass online audiences far from the courthouses where they are filed.

articles.headline: China Looks West to Bring ‘Wolf Totem’ to Screen
articles.snippet: “Wolf Totem,” a film by the French director Jean-Jacques Annaud, opens in China with Beijing’s approval.
articles.abstract: “Wolf Totem,” a film by the French director Jean-Jacques Annaud, opens in China with Beijing’s approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Ten years ago, when producers at the state-run Beijing Forbidden City Film Corporation began searching for a director for the movie adaptation of the Chinese novel “Wolf Totem” by Jiang Rong, they had no plans to look beyond China’s homegrown stable. It was a Chinese story, after all, written by a Chinese author, and had sold more than a million copies in this country in the year since its publication in 2004. (It has sold four million more there since.)

articles.headline: HSBC Chief Defends Swiss Bank Account Worth $7.7 Million
articles.snippet: Stuart Gulliver responded to news reports about the account, saying it was set up to keep his bonuses private from his colleagues.
articles.abstract: Stuart Gulliver responded to news reports about the account, saying it was set up to keep his bonuses private from his colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Already forced to apologize for helping clients hide their income from tax authorities, HSBC had to explain on Monday why its chief executive went to lengths for years to hide his bonus, at least from his co-workers.
